clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Parenteral Nutrition Supplement on Esophagectomy Patients
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Parenteral Nutrition Supplement Versus Enteral Nutrition Alone on Nutrition Status After Esophagectomy: A Prospective Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Malnutrition is common in esophagus cancer patients, especially after surgery therapy. Whether parenteral supplement with enteral nutrtion is benificial for patients after esophagectomy is controversial, when compared with enteral nutrition alone. In this study, the investigators are to examine the effect of enteral nutrition supplemented with parenteral nutrtion on nutrition status after esophagectomy.

primary_outcome.measure: postoperative laboratory parameters changes for nutrition assessment compared to preoperation
primary_outcome.time_frame: from one day before surgery to the 7th postoperative day
primary_outcome.description: plasma albumin, prealbumin, transferrin, retinaldehyde-binding protein, total lymphocytes counts

primary_outcome.measure: postoperative body composition change compared to preoperation measurement
primary_outcome.time_frame: from one day before surgery to the 7th postoperative day
primary_outcome.description: postoperative body composition is compared to preoperation, bioelectrical impedance spectroscopy is used for measurement of body composition

other_outcome.description: complications involve anastomotic leakage, incision infection, pneumonia, catherter-related blood stream infection, respiratory failure

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of esophagus cancer
- Undergo esophagectomy
- Nasoenteral tube is placed or surgical jejunostomy is performed
Exclusion Criteria:
- Contraindication for enteral nutrition or parenteral nutrition
- Malnutrition before surgery ( BMI > 30 or < 18.5)
- Hepatic dysfunction preoperatively
- Renal dysfunction preoperatively
- Infection before surgery
- Usage of corticosteroid before surgery
